entry.title: Introducing SAP HANA Cloud on SAP Cloud Infrastructure
entry.content:
We are pleased to share that SAP HANA Cloud is now generally available on SAP BTP powered by SAP Cloud Infrastructure. This new deployment option complements our existing offerings on hyperscaler platforms, addressing the growing demand for technological independence, local compliance, and data control.

About SAP Cloud Infrastructure

SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI) is SAP's own Infrastructure-as-a-Service (IaaS) platform, operated from SAP data centers around the globe. Built on OpenStack APIs, it provides hyperscale-like capabilities including compute, storage, and networking. Originally designed to run SAP cloud applications with high scalability, resilience, compliance, and security, SCI now also supports selected customer and partner workloads. To explore the platform and its features, visit the SAP Cloud Infrastructure Documentation.

How the new deployment fits into SAP's multi-cloud strategy

SAP gives customers the flexibility to run SAP HANA Cloud on the infrastructure that best meets their needs. Today, it's available on the leading hyperscalers—Amazon Web Services, Microsoft Azure, Google Cloud Platform, and Alibaba Cloud—leveraging our partners' global reach and modern infrastructure. See SAP HANA Cloud data centers.

By adding SAP Cloud Infrastructure as a deployment option alongside the hyperscalers, we give customers even more choice and flexibility, while meeting requirements for technological autonomy, data residency, and access control in the public cloud.

First region and initial scope

SAP HANA Cloud is now live in the SAP BTP Europe (Frankfurt) region on SCI. This cloud-in-country deployment keeps customer and backup data local, ensuring data residency and compliance.

Operating in EU Access mode, the SCI-based deployment restricts the processing of personally identifiable customer data to SAP delivery units located within the European Economic Area (EEA) and Switzerland, giving customers enhanced control and data protection.

On SCI, SAP HANA Cloud delivers the same capabilities and benefits as on hyperscalers*, along with the same SLAs and pricing models, ensuring a consistent experience regardless of deployment choice.

What's next?

SAP HANA Cloud is expanding alongside SAP BTP into new SCI regions. Additional SCI regions are planned for upcoming releases—check the latest SAP HANA Cloud data center availability in SAP Roadmap Explorer.

Summary

With SAP HANA Cloud, customers can choose the infrastructure provider that best fits their business—either a partner hyperscaler or SAP itself. The first SAP BTP region on SAP Cloud Infrastructure is Europe (Frankfurt). With EU-Access, in-country hosting, and enterprise-grade SLAs, this region provides compliance, security, and reliability, serving the specific needs of German and European customers.

*Restrictions at GA: (1) SAP HANA Cloud, Data lake Relational Engine, (2) Joule in SAP HANA Cloud Central, (3) Customer-managed encryption keys (CMK), and (4) memory sizes larger than 7.5 TB.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #4 in the Series
entry.content:
We’ve been talking in this about how you can build your business case for modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. However, many organizations still need help calculating the business value of migrating their database to the cloud.

A recent IDC study [1]  confirmed the value of modernizing to SAP HANA Cloud. Using a detailed business value assessmt methodology, IDC calculated that each SAP HANA Cloud database delivered US$820,000 in average annual benefits, with a 10.3-month payback on investment. Numbers like that are sure to turn heads.

This blog reviews the three beneficial features that can help you make the case for SAP HANA Cloud: native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines the duties of database developers and administrators.

Native AI capabilities

To gain value from huge volumes of business data, you need advanced AI capabilities that simplify the development and deployment of intelligent applications. 

SAP HANA Cloud is part of SAP Business Technology Platform, which offers powerful AI tools, frameworks, and services. These capabilities streamline the development and deployment of intelligent applications using machine learning and generative AI features. Extensive tools and resources, including prebuilt AI models, help you take advantage of business-ready AI.  

Multi-model engines process vast amounts of data and generate intelligent, in-context outputs. SAP HANA Cloud provides native storage, processing, and querying capabilities for AI data. A built-in vector engine handles embeddings as core data, so you can conduct similarity searches and rankings without creating separate vector databases. The database also supports retrieval-augmented generation, which helps large language models become more context-aware and integrate sensitive business context into data interactions.

SAP HANA Cloud also includes built-in, AI-enabled analytics that support predictive modeling, graph and similarity search, and time-series analysis. A predictive analysis library supports powerful features such as clustering, recommender systems, and outlier detection.  In addition, a library of 100+ business and scientific algorithms for key ML scenarios is embedded natively into the database. The IDC report suggests organizations can use these capabilities to automate insights and optimize decision-making by processing multiple data types. Study participants realized a 25% productivity increase, which translates into a value of $271,184 per enterprise.

Global cosmetics leader Natura &Co used the AI capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud with SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP) to create a similarity search. The vector engine feature of SAP HANA Cloud allows users to extract information from large volumes of documents using natural language. The company also plans to use the generative AI capability to streamline business processes and support faster decision-making in its implementation of SAP S/4HANA.

Built-in data integration

Your IT landscape is complex—with data flowing to and from multiple systems, cloud platforms, and on-premises environments. Bringing this data together has always required complex ETL processes, synchronization mechanisms, and data duplication efforts. How can you simplify the integration of this business data? Realistically, every business uses data sources provided by various vendors. To bring this data together requires smooth data integration.

SAP HANA Cloud offers native connectivity with almost any data source. You can access data from SAP and third-party applications, including ERP systems, IoT devices, and external data services. The database can gain live access to sources without data replication. This integration unifies disparate data streams and creates one holistic view of your enterprise data, allowing developers to build intelligent data applications that deliver accurate, current information in real time.  

Built-in data integration capabilities include:

  • Smart data access, offering virtual data access from source systems without physical data movement
  • Simple switching between virtual data access and data replication, balancing cost and performance effectively
  • Smart data integration, enabling real-time or batch data replication with transformation capabilities
  • Hybrid connectivity, with unified connection to on-premises SAP HANA systems

Multi-model capabilities combine federated relational data with other data types, including vector embedding, spatial information, graph relationships, and JSON documents. By eliminating traditional barriers between data sources and locations, SAP HANA Cloud helps you simplify data management while creating a connected enterprise data ecosystem.

In the IDC report, respondents said the ability to gain access to real-time data from a single source helped their analytics teams accelerate data reporting. One executive working in the retail industry said, “The data is far more accessible and quicker to get with SAP HANA Cloud.”

Automation to streamline DBA duties

The workload of database developers and administrators seems to grow endlessly, as data architectures become more complex. Whether they are diagnosing and resolving issues, tuning database performance, or writing queries, these workers face a long list of highly manual tasks.

Using integrated, AI-powered tooling available with SAP HANA Cloud helps administrators work more efficiently and productively. Conversational AI features help them generate SQL statements from plain text queries, create intelligent explanations of database behaviors or issues, and automatically summarize alerts and system messages into actionable insights.

SAP HANA Cloud also automates routine database maintenance issues. The database continuously monitors system usage and offers proactive recommendations for optimization. It can identify performance bottlenecks, guide resource tuning, and suggest areas ripe for elastic scaling. Administrators can get the job done with no deep technical intervention required. 

The benefits of automation are notable. In the IDC study, companies reported a 30% efficiency boost for their database administrator (DBA) teams, resulting in an average annual business value of $336,089 per organization.

One technology organization appreciated this value. “SAP HANA Cloud provides our DBA team with more tools to help identify issues and resolve them,” said the participant. “It has increased their productivity as a result.”

Another company in the agriculture industry concurred. “The fact that SAP HANA Cloud has centralized database administration and provided flexibility to add a data lake within its data source connections has positively impacted the productivity of our DBA team,” the executive added.

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the final blog to learn how comprehensive security and a complete development system can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

 

Additional resources:

What’s the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete a short assessment. 

Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.

Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.

Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

[1]  “The Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,” IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: Hello Python: My First Script in SAP BAS Connecting to HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Credit: @Vitaliy-R Your startup blogs kindled my interest to explore working with Python in SAP ecosystem. Python in BAS and Jupyter in BAS 

When I first started exploring SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), I was curious about how Python could fit into the SAP landscape. I’ve mostly associated BAS with HANA artefacts(SQLScript, hdbcalculationview, hdbreptask etc.) and CAP artefacts, so writing a Python script inside BAS felt like venturing into new territory. My goal was simple: write a basic script and connect it to SAP HANA Cloud. What I discovered along the way is that Python not only works smoothly in BAS but also makes it easy to interact with HANA Cloud, opening up opportunities for data exploration, automation, and integration in a way that feels both modern and approachable.

Before jumping into the Python script, I had to get my environment ready in SAP Business Application Studio (BAS). Here’s what I set up:

A BAS dev space with a full-stack cloud application space since it supports multiple runtimes, including Python. I had a space with HANA Native Application type. Since the Python tools extension is not added by default, I edited the space to select the Python tools in the additional extension options. 

HANA Dev Space Python extension

 Note: For initial steps to check the Python version, Jupyter notebook and set ups refer to the blogs listed at the start. 

Use Case: I attempted to achieve the following: 

  • Establish a connection to HANA Cloud
  • Execute an SQL query on a table/view 
  • Display the results

In the BAS, I created a project from Template: SAP HANA Database Project

 

Next step: Create a notebook file. 

My guide to connect to HANA Cloud: Connect to HANA Cloud 

When I first tried importing hdbcli into my Jupyter Notebook within BAS, I ran into the same ModuleNotFoundError. Even though I had already installed hdbcli In the terminal, the notebook kernel wasn’t recognizing it. On some search and prompting with GPT( 😁), I understood that it's a common issue because Jupyter can run in a different Python environment than the terminal. The fix was simple: I ran

import sys
!{sys.executable} -m pip install hdbcli

directly in a notebook cell. This ensures that the HANA client is installed in the same environment as the notebook kernel. After this step, I could successfully import dbapi and connect to HANA Cloud without any errors. It was a small but important lesson about Python environments in BAS, especially when using Jupyter.

With the hdbcli package installed and working in my Jupyter Notebook, I was ready to write my first Python script to connect to SAP HANA Cloud.

In the next cell, I imported hdbcli in this notebook. 

import hdbcli
print(hdbcli.__file__)

 

 The next step was to gain access to the dbapi interface, which allows you to establish connections, execute SQL queries, and fetch results from your HANA Cloud instance. This simple import is the gateway to working with HANA directly from Python.

from hdbcli import dbapi

The next step is to establish a connection to your HANA Cloud instance. This requires specifying the host, port, username, and password.

 After connecting, you can create a cursor object to execute SQL statements. An SQL statement, preferably a Select Query to test the retrieval of data from HANA Cloud. In my case, I used a Select with count on the number of records in a view. Once the variables were ready, execute the connection cursor object.

Note: in the SQL variable, use single quotes and a semicolon at the end of the query. (beginner tip 🙂 )

Now is the time to test the data retrieval from the script and compare it with the Database Explorer.

Drum roll....🥁

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Hurray 🎉

Completing my first Python script in SAP Business Application Studio and connecting it to HANA Cloud was an exciting milestone. From the initial curiosity to the small hurdles like installing hdbcli in the notebook and finally seeing my script return results, every step felt like a mini victory.

That simple output from HANA Cloud made all the effort worthwhile and gave me a real sense of accomplishment.

This experience has sparked my curiosity to explore more complex queries, data analysis, and automation using Python in SAP.

I hope my journey inspires others to take that first step and discover how fun and powerful working with Python and HANA Cloud can be.

Chao.

entry.title: What’s New in SAP HANA Cloud – September 2025
entry.content:
What’s New in SAP HANA Cloud – September 2025

As we approach the end of the third quarter of 2025, we are thrilled to present the third release of SAP HANA Cloud for the year. Certainly, this quarterly update brings many innovative features designed to enhance your experience with SAP HANA Cloud and drive business value.



Let’s explore the exciting new capabilities and improvements that have just been made available.

 

Innovations in SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Database

Administration and Service Management

Bulk Alert configuration

Starting off strong, the Q3 release introduces bulk alert configuration. Building on previous alert configuration methods and REST API-based bulk management, alert rule sets offer a graphical interface for bulk alert configuration accessible to all administrators without API expertise. The feature also allows to create and save alert configuration templates, making it easy to reuse them across different instances.

Bulk alert configuration significantly enhances user efficiency by streamlining the alert setup process. Management of complex alert configurations becomes more scalable, while safeguarding that all instances are monitored effectively without the need for repetitive manual setup.

To learn more about this new feature, take a look at this blog post by our product expert Hai Zhang.  

Partition Advisor

The Recommendation App, housing all intelligent advisors for SAP HANA Cloud, hosts a new advisor, as we introduce the partition advisor with QRC3 2025. It helps maintain manageable partition sizes by automatically analyzing potential partition keys and methods (range versus hash). It provides recommendations on how to partition your data effectively and can apply these recommendations via an “Apply” button to your tables.

The Partition Advisor saves time by automating the analysis of partitioning options and delivering actionable recommendations. It helps users identify tables that may exceed the limits, suggesting optimal repartitioning strategies. This not only improves query performance but also optimizes costs, ensuring that your data management remains efficient and scalable.

Find more information about the partition advisor in this help documentation. 

Support for 9 TB instances on Microsoft Azure

From now on, SAP HANA Cloud on Microsoft Azure supports large instances up to 9TB. Please note that the availability of these large database instances will vary depending on your selected region.

With the support for 9 TB instances on Azure, businesses gain the flexibility to scale up their databases as needed. It allows them to handle increased memory requirements, while ensuring that their database can keep pace with growing data demands. This scalability is crucial for maintaining optimal performance and supporting business growth.

Finding object dependencies in database objects

Dependencies are now shown in the properties page of schema objects such as tables, views, functions, and procedures in the database objects app.  This enables you to quickly examine the dependencies between objects. 

As seen below in the Database Objects app, the table CUSTOMER has an incoming referential dependency from the RESERVATION table and is referenced in a view and function.  A graphical dependency viewer is also available in the SAP HANA database explorer extension in SAP Business Application Studio or Visual Studio Code. 

Simplified Instance Provisioning

The SAP HANA Cloud provisioning wizard has been enhanced to enable users to select either a preset configuration, provide a JSON configuration, or to use a manual configuration when creating new instances. 


The preset configurations for SAP HANA databases include basic, minimum, maximum, last used, and most used, enabling a user to quickly choose a preset that closely matches their use case.  After filling in a few required fields such as instance name and password, the instance can be created.  Basic is sized to support additional features such as the document store, triple store, natural language processing, and the script and data provisioning servers.   

The JSON configuration option enables a user to create instances based on a JSON document that contains the settings of the instance.  This can be helpful if you wish to create multiple instances with very similar configurations. 

Finally, the manual configuration option enables a user to explore all the possible configuration setting using the instance wizard. 

 

SQL Console statement library

With the QRC3 release of SAP HANA Cloud, the statement library in the SQL Console of SAP HANA Cloud Central has the option to run and open multiple statements either in the current tab or in individual tabs.   

Run will append the statements together and the results will be shown in separate result set tabs. 

Run in Individual Tabs opens each selected statement in its own SQL Console tab and executes it. 

Data Integration

Introducing the New Data Access Agent - connecting to Azure SQL Database & Snowflake

Additionally, I am thrilled to announce that SAP HANA smart data access (SDA) now supports Microsoft Azure SQL database and Snowflake as remote sources via the new Data Access Agent. This new Data Access Agent expands data federation and provides broader coverage with JDBC-based adapters as an SAP-managed service.

With a clean core strategy in mind, SDA is a core component to leverage the full potential of your data. Until recently, the limited protocol boundaries to ODBC and REST as well as restrictions on running 3rd party drivers, limited the supported scope of remote resources. SAP HANA smart data integration (SDI) helped to bridge this gap but required customers to deploy and operate the Data Provisioning Agent (DPAgent) in an on-premise setup.

The new Data Access Agent now supports new JDBC-based adapters. Of course, the natively available SDA adapters continue to be based on ODBC and REST. The SAP-managed Data Access Agent simplifies operations and reduces the effort to access Microsoft Azure SQL Database and the Snowflake in SAP HANA Cloud. Users can also benefit from streamlined and user-friendly configuration and monitoring of this fully managed, secure, and cloud native product.

Please note the new Data Access Agent currently only supports data federation and snapshot toggling within the virtual table interface. Real-time replication is not supported. Refer to further details of support in SAP Note 2600176 - SAP HANA Smart Data Access Supported Remote Sources.

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud's New Data Access Agent, take a look at @SeungjoonLee 's  blog post here.

Support a remote source to SharePoint in Microsoft 365 

Moreover, with the Q3 release we introduce support for creating a remote source to SharePoint in Microsoft 365 using the data access agent of SAP HANA smart data access. This feature allows for the virtualization of data, including lists and Excel worksheets, within SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database. For further details on supported remote sources, refer to SAP Note 2600176.

With the ability to access SharePoint data in Microsoft 365 through the SAP-managed data access agent, users can simplify operations and reduce the effort required for data integration. This eventually enhances collaboration and streamlines data management processes.

Direct SQL access to files in the Apache Iceberg open table format

Furthermore, with the recent release we introduce direct SQL access to files in the Apache Iceberg’s open table format. This enhancement enables users to create virtual tables within SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database, allowing read-only access to Apache Iceberg data in external object storage. Supported storage types include the data lake files in SAP HANA Cloud, Amazon S3, Azure Blob Storage, Azure Data Lake Storage (ADLS) Gen2, and Google Cloud Storage.

This means users can execute SQL queries on large volumes of data without the need to load it into the memory of the SAP HANA database. The new feature thus enhances performance and efficiency, enabling seamless data analysis across diverse storage environments.

Security

Row-level data access control over fact tables based on associated dimension attributes

Next, SAP HANA Cloud now supports row-level data access control over fact tables based on associated dimension attributes. This allows users to restrict access to fact table data without the need to join the dimension tables where the access control is applied. Restrictions are based on the availability of associated dimensional data, which is already restricted with a structured filter (=nested structured filters).

This capability enables fine-grain access control to restrict data for fact tables based on associated dimension table attribute data. This enhances security and ensures that sensitive data is accessible only to authorized users, improving overall data governance.

Support for X509-based dynamic user creation

Moreover, SAP HANA Cloud also supports X509-based dynamic user creation, leveraging the Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (LDAP). Customers can now create user data automatically in SAP HANA Cloud based on X509 authentication and manage user data within related LDAP groups.

Bridging the gap for automated user creation through X509 authentication with user authorization through LDAP, this feature allows for the automation of user creation. This strengthens operational efficiency and streamlines user management processes, ensuring a seamless integration of security protocols.

Support for Azure Private Link

Over the past quarters, there have already been announcements about different private IP endpoint service deliveries. From Q3 2025 on, SAP HANA Cloud now supports Azure Private Link as well, enabling users to connect applications running within an Azure landscape to SAP HANA Cloud, SAP HANA database using private IP endpoints. These endpoints are addressable only within the Azure network and are not exposed publicly, ensuring an additional layer of security. It is important to note that services in SAP HANA Cloud already enforce strict transport layer security (TLS) and allow users to configure IP allow or disallow lists.

With Azure Private Link support, users can significantly reduce the exposure of IP endpoints, enhancing the overall security of connections to SAP HANA Cloud. This feature complements existing IP allow or disallow list filtering, ensuring that sensitive data remains protected and secure within the Azure network.

Multi-Model Data Processing

Vector Embedding SQL Function Support for Generative AI Hub

With the recent release, SAP HANA Cloud once again expands its vector embedding support by allowing the VECTOR_EMBEDDING SQL function to directly use embedding models exposed via SAP GenAI Hub. 

Previously, the function only supported SAP-provided NLP models. Now, customers can connect their own SAP GenAI Hub service instance and consume any available embedding model, for example OpenAI, Amazon Titan, or other partner models directly via SQL. 

All one must do is:

  • Create a remote source in SAP HANA Cloud that points to your SAP GenAI Hub (AI Core) service instance 
  • Configure certificates and authentication controls 
  • Retrieve available models with GET_REMOTE_SOURCE_AI_MODELS built-in procedure 
  • Call VECTOR_EMBEDDING by passing the text, type (e.g. DOCUMENT), model name and version, and the remote source 

For detailed setup and examples, see here. 

Support for Batch Embedding Creation using CREATE VECTOR EMBEDDINGS

SAP HANA Cloud also introduces a newly built-in procedure CREATE_VECTOR_EMBEDDINGS that makes it easier to generate vector embeddings for large volumes of text data stored in SAP HANA tables. Instead of having to process documents row by row, this procedure lets you embed text in batches. You simply provide the table and column that contain your documents, specify the target vector column, choose the NLP model, and the procedure automatically generates embeddings where they are missing. 

This new capability simplifies and accelerates the integration of AI and NLP use cases with SAP HANA Cloud, by reducing time to value for building intelligent applications with embeddings and by allowing developers to process large datasets more efficiently with built-in batch handling. It also eliminates repetitive boilerplate code for embedding creation and storage. 

To summarize, this makes SAP HANA Cloud a more powerful foundation for scenarios such as semantic search, generative AI, and intelligent text analysis. For detailed syntax and examples, see here. 

JSON as a datatype in the SAP HANA Cloud JSON Document Store

With QRC3 2025, SAP HANA Cloud introduces JSON as a datatype in the Document Store. This is not a column data type for tables, but a return type for collections in the Document Store. 

Collections can now return JSON directly instead of NVARCHAR, so queries follow JSON semantics without extra casting. This brings clearer path access with the $ root specifier, better performance through filter and function pushdown, and simpler syntax when working with JSON content. 

By making JSON a first class return type, SAP HANA Cloud improves both efficiency and consistency when building applications on flexible document data. For detailed syntax and examples, see here.

Please note, the ‘$’ document root specifier is mandatory for collections returning JSON. Existing collections will still default to NVARCHAR unless explicitly created or altered to return JSON. Some casts (like TO_NVARCHAR on complex types) are restricted for JSON return types.  

Graphical View Modeling

The third release in 2025 again brings many enhancements to SAP HANA Cloud’s graphical view modeling capabilities. Below, we are giving an overview about the innovations introduced. To get more details, you can take a closer look at Jan Zwickel's blog post .

Ability to rename multiple already mapped columns

Let’s start with the new ability to rename multiple columns that are already mapped, allowing users to perform this action in a single step. This feature is available for star joins and in the node mapping dialog.

This new capability simplifies the refactoring of column names and enhances model insights by enabling users to provide more-specific and meaningful column names. This increases the clarity and usability of data models, improving overall user experience.

Flexibly maintaining labels for alias names

Additionally, users can now flexibly maintain labels for alias names by using expressions. For example, users can generate a label that transforms the alias name to lowercase and adds a prefix.

This feature not only increases development efficiency and improves model quality but also provides a better analytics user experience by ensuring that labels are consistent and meaningful, eventually enhancing the readability and interpretability of data models.

Support of semijoin functionality

Furthermore, the semijoin functionality is now available. This feature enables users to effectively reduce records based on filter values by providing a dedicated join option for filtering in standard join nodes.

The semijoin functionality optimizes resource consumption when filtering through joins, allowing users to more efficiently manage data processing tasks. It enhances performance and ensures that only relevant data is processed, leading to improved overall efficiency and resource utilization.

Switching between structured privileges and structured filters through a graphical editor

Next, we introduced the capability to switch between structured privileges and structured filters using a graphical editor. Users can now change from one object type to another seamlessly and store the changes accordingly.

This increases flexibility when creating analytic privileges, allowing users to easily switch between privilege types to meet their specific requirements. The graphical editor enhances the overall usability and efficiency of managing data insights.

Improved supportability by SQL plan trace for EPM, MDS, and prepared statement caches

Moreover, supportability for SAP HANA Cloud got improved by enabling SQL plan trace for EPM (Enterprise Performance Management) queries, MDS (Multidimensional Services) queries, and prepared statement caches. 

By enabling plan trace for EPM, MDS queries, and prepared statement caches, this feature allows for better troubleshooting and performance analysis. It increases the overall supportability and reliability of these systems, ensuring that users can get the assistance they need when issues arise.

MDS Cubes

Support of input parameters in multidimensional services (MDS) cubes

With the Q3 release, users can now select combinations of input parameter values that will be loaded and served by the MDS cube. This functionality extends the capabilities of MDS cubes, allowing for more flexible and dynamic data insights.

The support for input parameters in MDS cubes increases the scope of scenarios that can be handled, providing users with more comprehensive and tailored insights. Thus, this feature helps users receive insights more quickly, enhancing the overall analytics experience and improving operational efficiency of SAP HANA Cloud.

Using additional currency conversion options with MDS cube

Besides, the recent release enables the use of additional currency conversion options with MDS cubes. Users can now employ rounding, decimal shifts, and the accuracy option "retain all possible digits" in conjunction with MDS cubes.

These additional currency conversion options simplify the creation of MDS cubes from existing calculation views while providing greater flexibility and control over currency data, and ensuring accurate and consistent financial insights.

Using unit conversion of MDS cube measures together with the option to convert at query execution time

Additionally, users are now able to convert units of MDS cube measures during query execution time.

By allowing the unit conversion at query execution time, users gain increased control over when and how unit conversion happens thus enhancing the flexibility and accuracy of data analysis, while also ensuring that units are converted as needed for specific insights.

 

Innovations in SAP HANA Cloud, data lake

Single Sign on support for SAP HANA Cloud, data lake files

The Data Lake Files app in SAP HANA Cloud Central now supports Single Sign-On (SSO) in addition to X509 credentials for authentication.  

It can be enabled with the “Enable Single Sign-On for Data Lake Files” menu item from the actions menu in either the Instances or Data Lake Files app. 

This feature enables users to quickly use the Data Lake Files app without having to do configuration steps required to use X509 authentication. 

 

Further Innovations & Enhancements

SAP HANA Client

Our SAP HANA Client for Python now supports Alpine Linux x64 as of the 2.25 release.  Alpine Linux is a security-oriented, lightweight Linux distribution.  Alpine Linux offers several benefits, such as faster build times due to its lightweight nature and enhanced security with fewer vulnerabilities due to its minimalism.   

However, unlike most Linux distributions, Alpine Linux uses musl libc instead of glibc. While this keeps Alpine lean, it breaks compatibility with the regular Linux x64 SAP HANA Client package and requires its own separate Python wheel release.  It can be found on PyPI at https://pypi.org/project/hdbcli/ 

For further details on the platforms that the SAP HANA Client supports, please see SAP Note 3165810 - SAP HANA Client Supported Platforms 

Expanded Data Center Availability on SAP Cloud Infrastructure in Germany

With QRC3 2025, we are introducing SAP HANA Cloud on SAP Cloud Infrastructure (SCI) — SAP's own cloud infrastructure, operated in SAP data centers. This new deployment option expands the existing SAP HANA Cloud offering on leading hyperscaler infrastructure (AWS, Azure, GCP, and AliCloud) and meets the growing demand for technological independence, local compliance, and data control. 

Today, SAP HANA Cloud is available on SCI in Frankfurt, Germany. With EU-Access, in-country hosting, and enterprise-grade SLAs, this region offers compliance, security, and reliability for German and European customers. Additional SCI regions are planned for upcoming releases. Check SAP HANA Cloud Data Center Availability in SAP Roadmap Explorer. 

To learn more about SAP HANA Cloud on SCI, take a look at this this blog post.  

Database Application Development

Natural language to SQL generation in Joule using SAP Build Code

Last but not least, we introduce the generation of SQL for SAP HANA Cloud in Joule using SAP Build Code. This feature allows users to generate SQL statements based on natural language input. Additionally, it copies the generated SQL statement to the SQL consoles of the database explorer extension for SAP HANA in SAP Build Code.

This feature increases developer productivity by automating the process of generating SQL statements through natural language input. It reduces the likelihood of errors and improves the quality of the generated SQL, ultimately streamlining the development process and enhancing efficiency.

Great job reading through the entire Q3 2025 What's New blog post!

To dive deeper into the technical specifics of the Q3 2025 release, be sure to check out our What’s New Viewer in the Technical documentation. It offers a detailed overview of the release scope. To stay updated on the latest developments and news surrounding SAP HANA Cloud, follow the SAP HANA Cloud tag.

Additionally, you can discover our latest blog posts by searching for the #whatsnewinsaphanacloud hashtag. If you missed the previous What’s New webinar from Q2 2025, you can find it along with past recordings and future webinars in this YouTube playlist. Our upcoming webcast on the Q3 innovations will be added to the same playlist soon.

Have questions about SAP HANA Cloud or want to discuss the new innovations? Feel free to post them in our SAP HANA Cloud Community Q&A or in the comments section below!

Cheers!

entry.title: From REST to Datasphere: A CAP-based Integration Approach
entry.content:
From REST to Datasphere: A CAP-based Integration Approach

We recently wrote a blog about how we integrate data from a REST service into SAP Datasphere. For that we deployed a small service on SAP BTP, which used the OPEN SQL schema and FastAPI to write this data directly into Datasphere. That service could also be triggered via REST endpoint from SAP Datasphere directly (ZPARTNER Link, SAP Community Link).

In this blog we now choose a different setup to retrieve data and consume it into SAP Dataphere.

We Created a CAP Application on SAP BTP.

This CAP service connects to the SCIM API of SAP Datasphere, extracts users and roles, and makes the data consumable for analytics. It uses the following BTP services:

  • HDI Container
    To persist our data from the REST calls. The HDI container is deployed to the HANA Cloud instance of our Datasphere tenant, so the data can be consumed directly.
  • BTP Credential Store
    We store the credentials for the SCIM API in the BTP Credential Store and retrieve them in our CAP application securely.
  • XSUAA Authorization and Trust Management
    To secure our REST endpoints and enforce token-based access control.
  • Cloud Foundry Space
    Provides the runtime environment for deploying the CAP application.

Use Case

In our use case, we extract user information from SAP Datasphere’s own SCIM API.

We retrieve:

  • the list of users,
  • all available roles, and
  • the assignments between users and roles.

This can be helpful for reporting on the number of users in a tenant and their corresponding roles. However, the same setup can be reused to extract and process any other REST API data into SAP Datasphere.

Credential Store

We create a dedicated namespace in the Credential Store and store four secrets for the SCIM API authentication flow:

  • dsp-scim-token-url
  • dsp-scim-base-url
  • dsp-scim-client-id
  • dsp-scim-client-secret

The CAP application retrieves these secrets at runtime, ensuring no credentials are hardcoded.

XSUAA Authorization and Trust Management Service

We create a dedicated xsuaa service to get a Token URL and credentials. This service is bound to our CAP application so that every incoming request is authorized and protected.

HDI Container

We create an HDI container where the database artifacts (tables and associations) are deployed. This container is provisioned in our SAP Datasphere tenant, making the synchronized data directly available for consumption.

CAP Application

The heart of the solution is the CAP service DSPUsers.

It exposes two kinds of endpoints:

Virtual Views (live from SCIM)

  • GET /data/UsersVH → List of users with profile info.
  • GET /data/RolesVH → Roles with aggregated user counts.
  • GET /data/UserRolesVH → Which users have which roles.

These views are always fresh, since they query SCIM directly.

Persistent Entities (stored in HDI)

  • GET /data/Users → Users persisted in HANA.
  • GET /data/Roles → Roles persisted in HANA.
  • GET /data/UserRoles → User-to-role assignments persisted in HANA.

Actions (to sync SCIM → HDI)

  • POST /data/SyncUsersVHToUsers → Upserts SCIM users into the Users table.
  • POST /data/SyncRolesFromSCIM → Stores aggregated roles in the Roles table.
  • POST /data/SyncUserRolesFromSCIM → Refreshes both Roles and UserRoles.

This design lets you both query SCIM data live and persist snapshots into HANA for modeling in Datasphere.

The complete CAP service code is available here: Link to GitHub Repository.

SAP Datasphere

Once deployed, the HDI container is automatically integrated with our SAP Datasphere tenant. This allows:

  • Consuming the Users, Roles, and UserRoles tables directly in Datasphere,
  • Building reporting scenarios on top of user and role data,
  • Joining with other business data to enrich analytics.

To consume the entities, we need to add the HDI Container to a specific space. Also, we can now create a generic HTTP Connection. This enables to call the Endpoints for sync in a Task Chain.

Conclusion

The integration of a CAP-based service into SAP Datasphere showcases how SAP BTP services (HDI Container, Credential Store, XSUAA, Cloud Foundry) can be combined to securely retrieve and persist data from external REST APIs. By consuming SAP Datasphere’s own SCIM API, we demonstrated how to expose both live views for real-time insights and persistent tables for analytical modeling, all within a lightweight and extensible architecture.

Looking ahead, this framework can be reused for any REST API integration into SAP Datasphere, opening the door to richer reporting scenarios, advanced data modeling, and seamless orchestration with Task Chains. With this foundation, organizations gain a simple but powerful pattern for bridging external services with Datasphere while maintaining enterprise-grade security and governance.

entry.title: What’s New in SAP Build – Q3 2025 Release Highlights
entry.content:
In Q3, we delivered several innovations across AI-powered development, ABAP project creation, modernized SAPUI5 and advanced mobile capabilities. SAP Build also reached a significant milestone with the introduction of MCP servers, allowing developers to boost productivity further with AI agents. 

Check these out in our Top 10 Release Highlights from Q3 2025! 

AI-powered development

1. Empowering developers with MCP Tools for SAP Build 

Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers are now available for the following technologies: SAP Cloud Application Programming Model (CAP), SAPUI5 and SAP Fiori. This is a huge step forward for developers working with popular IDEs and coding assistants like GitHub Copilot, Cursor and more. With these MCP servers, we’re now providing a comprehensive set of tools designed to optimize your development workflow across various SAP technologies.

Learn more in the blog post.

2. SAP HANA Cloud SQL Statement Generation in Joule

Directly in SAP Build Code, the Joule panel now offers the new command /hana-sql-gen, which enables the generation of SQL statements from natural language directly in the panel. The generated statements can be reviewed and refined in the Joule panel. Suitable SQL statements can be either copied to a SQL console or directly executed inside the Joule panel after selecting a database connection on which to run the statement.

3. Expanded AI-powered capabilities in SAP Build Work Zone

SAP Build Work Zone continues to expand its AI capabilities, bringing new built-in features to an intelligent workspace with accelerated decision-making and improved employee experiences:

  • Integration of Joule in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition: By bringing Joule into SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition, users can now enjoy the power of Joule within their digital workplace. This eliminates the hassle of system-hopping, reduces time wasted on searching for information, and allows employees to focus on what is important. (Note: Available in early October)
  • AI-powered text and comment generation: This enables employees to quickly create, summarize, and engage with workplace content. For example, project managers can generate project status updates in minutes, ensuring their team members stay aligned.

Learn more in the blog post.

Enhanced App Development & Automation

4. Availability of SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free with deprecated code removed 

SAPUI5 1.136.x-legacy-free with deprecated code removed is now available via cloud access. This means app developers can test their UI code for compliance to SAPUI5 best practices. This helps to future-proof an SAP Fiori app for future SAPUI5 versions and work on deprecated/outdated code. Developers can also provide feedback to the UI5 team.

Learn more in the blog post.

5. Create full-stack ABAP projects in SAP Build

You can now create full-stack ABAP projects or open an existing ABAP CSN as a project in SAP Build. You can also model your application using the CDS Graphical Modeler and generate ABAP development objects. By leveraging high productivity tools, this significantly accelerates time-to-market, improves collaboration and provides a standardized, compliant approach to building extensions.

Learn more in the Help Portal. ..And stay tuned! We’ll share more about this topic at SAP TechEd 2025.

6. Maintenance project for released process automation projects

For process automation, we’ve introduced the ability to create dedicated project versions based on an existing released version. This allows process owners to maintain parallel editable versions while keeping the latest version in place, enabling teams to focus on solving a problem without redoing everything from scratch.

Learn more in the Help Portal.

7. Outbox functionality for tasks in SAP Task Center

SAP Task Center, which provides a seamless user experience for accessing open tasks, now lets you view completed tasks in an outbox. This provides a complete view of historical data while reducing support requests and efforts around process automation instances.

New innovations for mobile

8. UI enhancements available for mobile development

The latest release of SAP Mobile Development Kit (MDK) is now available to customers, bringing with it multiple enhancements for UI creation. Developers can add a date range to their calendar controls, enable a read-only state, add required fields to forms, and much more.

Learn more in the latest blog post.

9. Support for new site experience in SAP Build Work Zone, advanced edition 

Employees accessing their workspace content via SAP Mobile Start can now enjoy a new view mode with a more flexible structuring of content. They can quickly view workspace updates, company news or project dashboards, making it easier to organize and consume information in a personalized way. (Note: Available in early October)

 

10. Updates to SAP Mobile Start

As the native mobile entry point to all SAP business apps and content, SAP Mobile Start has released several new innovations that simplify employee tasks and optimize their user experience:

  • SAP Document AI integration: Allows users to upload documents and photos for automated processing. This streamlines document handling, cuts down manual work and ensures data accuracy throughout operations.
  • Enhanced push notifications with more detailed information: Load and display context-specific details directly in the push notification, providing more meaningful and informative messages.
  • Simplified onboarding via deep link: IT teams can invite users to onboard to SAP Mobile Start via an email or message and provide a deep link that the users can use to initiate a simplified onboarding process.
  • Top news on start screen: Shows the most important news in a larger format on top of the Start screen.

Learn more in the latest blog post and Help Portal.

Ready to see these in action?

Join us for the next What’s New in SAP Build Webinar on October 8th as we dive deeper into MCP servers in CAP, SAP Mobile Start innovations, and much more!

Sign up today for your preferred option:
🌐October 8th, 9:00-10:00am CEST (EMEA/APJ friendly): Register here
🌐October 8th, 5:00-6:00pm CEST (Americas friendly): Register here

entry.title: Fast Track Your Transition to SAP Business Data Cloud! 🌩️
entry.content:
Hello SAP Community! 👋

Whether you’re a seasoned data architect or just beginning your cloud journey, navigating the move to SAP Business Data Cloud is a hot topic. Inspired by our recent interactive webinar, let’s recap key insights — and invite you to share your own!

 

🌟Why Embrace SAP Business Data Cloud?

  • Empower both people and AI agents with up-to-the-minute analytics and packaged data products.

  • Make “data as a product” — not just a byproduct — your standard, giving everyone context, semantics, and self-service.

  • Spark a culture of citizen data stewardship, freeing up IT to innovate!

  

🧭 Pillars for a Winning Transition

  • Persona-Centricity: Solutions must work for technical teams, business leaders, AND the growing “citizen” analyst.

  • Lakehouse Architecture: Combine cost-effective storage with lightning-fast analytics — all using open formats.

  • Data Productization: Out-of-the-box, ready-to-consume data models to power your analytics and AI.

  • Open Connectivity: Break down silos and connect SAP & non-SAP data seamlessly.

  • Data Harmonization: Share and exchange trusted data across domains, finally reducing friction!

 

🔁Interactive Paths to BDC

  • BW Modernization: Still on BW 7.5? Lift-and-shift to BDC extends support and unlocks automated data product generation.

  • HANA Cloud Migration: Bring your trusted HANA models forward, integrate with powerful engines, and publish new data products instantly.

  • Analytics Cloud “Rewire”: Plug your Data Sphere and SAC directly into BDC. No re-engineering, just more value.

  • Zero-Copy Sharing (Databricks fans, this is for you!): Share data and semantics directly into advanced AI/ML scenarios.

 

 

🛠️ Community Resources at Your Fingertips

  • SAP Discovery Center: Stay current with FAQs and technical guides.

  • Architecture Center: Grab and customize diagrams, share your patterns, and learn from validated community posts.

  • Accelerator Hub: Browse SAP data products and packages for every industry.

  • Roadmap Explorer: Track features, data center rollouts, and future capabilities.

  • Trust Center: Review compliance, security, and data residency—key for every architect!

 

👥What’s Your Transition Story?

We want your input! Which transition path is top-of-mind in your organization? Have another innovative approach? Drop your experiences, questions, or favorite resources in the comments below. Let’s shape this journey together.

 

🏁Ready to Take Action?

  • Sign up for the free BDC assessment and get personalized insights. 

  • Ask about discovery workshops and premium engagement for tailored guidance.

  • Bookmark this blog and join our next community session for more best practices and live demos! (Registration Link)

 

A special thank you to our guest, @hmohammed , for providing valuable insights and sharing his experiences with the participants

entry.title: Time-series Forecasting with Generative AI: Integrating HANA AI Toolkit with Joule in SAP Build Code
entry.content:
Introduction

In the era of AI-first development, embedding intelligence into business applications is no longer optional—it's expected. As an application developer working on SAP BTP, I was recently tasked with enhancing our Sales Refunds Analysis application with a forecasting component. The challenge? I’m not a data scientist.

But thanks to the HANA AI Toolkit and Joule, SAP Build Code’s AI co-pilot, I was able to build a robust forecasting solution—without needing deep expertise in machine learning.

In this blog, I’ll walk you through how I used a simple slash command /hana-ai to interact with the HANA AI Toolkit via Joule, and how this integration empowered me to build, evaluate, and deploy a forecasting model in just a few conversational steps.

What is the HANA AI Toolkit?

The Generative AI Toolkit for SAP HANA Cloud is a powerful suite of tools designed to simplify the use of SAP HANA’s machine learning and vector capabilities. It includes:

  • Conversational agents for building forecasting models
  • Tools for selecting and applying ML algorithms
  • SmartDataFrame interface for natural language data exploration
  • Vector and embedding services
  • Code generation components for SAP HANA Cloud scenarios

Meet Joule: Your AI Co-Pilot in SAP Build Code

Joule is SAP Build Code’s generative AI assistant, designed to help developers write, generate, and integrate code faster. With the new /hana-ai slash command, Joule can now directly interact with the HANA AI Toolkit—bringing ML capabilities into the hands of every developer.

My Use Case: Forecasting Sales Refunds

Here’s how I used the integration to build a forecasting model for our Sales Refunds application:

1. Initiating the Forecasting Task

/hana-ai I am tasked to create a forecasting application, do you have any hana-ai tools which can help me with that?

Joule responded with a list of ready-to-use forecasting tools like:

  • additive_model_forecast_fit_and_save
  • automatic_timeseries_fit_and_save
  • intermittent_forecast

 

2. Exploring the Data

/hana-ai Show me the first 5 rows from SALES_REFUNDS table

Joule fetched the data, helping me understand the structure and values.

 

3. Generating a Dataset Report

A detailed HTML report was generated, giving me insights into data quality and structure.

 

4. Time Series Analysis

 
/hana-ai Please analyse and check the time series data in the table SALES_REFUNDS_TRAIN

Joule analyzed the dataset and provided:

  • Stationarity check (KPSS test)
  • Seasonality detection
  • Intermittency level
  • Suggested algorithms and many more details

 

5. Choosing the Right Algorithm

 
/hana-ai Which time series forecasting algorithm do you suggest?

Based on the data characteristics, Joule recommended the Additive Model Forecast.

 

6. Building the Forecast Model

 
/hana-ai Build a forecast model and save it as Refunds-ForecastModel

The model was trained and saved with versioning support.

 

 

7. Generating Predictions

 
/hana-ai Apply the latest forecast model to the SALES_REFUNDS_PREDICT table

Predictions were stored in a new table, ready for analysis.

8. Visualizing the Forecast

 
/hana-ai Generate a forecast line plot

A visual plot was generated to compare actual vs. predicted values.

 

 

9. Evaluating Accuracy

 
/hana-ai Evaluate the forecast accuracy

Joule returned key metrics:

  • MAPE: 8.41%
  • MSE: 16,807,501.57
  • RMSE: 4,099.70

 

10. Generating CAP Artifacts

 
/hana-ai Generate CAP artifacts for the forecast model

Joule generated and offered to integrate the artifacts directly into my CAP project.

Outcome

With just a few conversational commands, I was able to:

  • Analyze time series data
  • Select the right forecasting model
  • Train and evaluate the model
  • Visualize and integrate the results into my application

All without writing a single line of ML code.

Key Takeaways

  • AI democratization: Developers without ML expertise can now build intelligent features.
  • Conversational development: Joule + HANA AI Toolkit enables natural language-driven workflows.
  • Enterprise-ready: The integration supports versioning, evaluation, and CAP artifact generation.

What’s Next?

This is just the beginning. With the /hana-ai slash command, we’re opening the door to a wide range of AI-powered development scenarios—from classification to anomaly detection and beyond.

If you're building on SAP BTP and want to embed intelligence into your applications, give the HANA AI Toolkit and Joule a try. You might be surprised how far a conversation can take you.

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #5 in the Series
entry.content:
This is the final chapter in this blog series on the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In each blog, I’ve described key features that offer significant benefits for your organization and can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

Although it can be difficult calculating the business value of migrating your database to the cloud, the expertise of independent organizations can be helpful. A recent IDC study[1]  used a specialized business value methodology to assess the benefits of SAP HANA Cloud delivered to participating organizations. IDC concluded that the benefits were worth an annual average of US$13.7 million per organization and that the database enabled a 35% three-year reduction in total cost of ownership.

If you don’t have time to read this report, I encourage you to complete your own organization assessment using our free tool. In less than five minutes, you’ll receive useful insights that can help you decide your next steps.

 

Let’s consider two more features of SAP HANA Cloud that can help you realize significant business value: comprehensive security and a complete application development ecosystem.

Comprehensive security

Protecting your data and helping ensure compliance are top concerns for every organization. As business operations and workforces become more distributed, the need to provide secure data access from anywhere in the world intensifies.

SAP HANA Cloud offers robust security features that cover critical data protection areas, including authentication, authorization, user management, data masking, anonymization, and encryption. Because these features are built into the database, you have little or no need for third-party security tools. These capabilities also reduce the administrative effort needed to protect data.

Support for multiple security certifications and standards, such as ISO (International Organization for Standardization) and SOC (Standard Occupational Classification), helps ensure regulatory compliance. Configurable audit policies streamline compliance activities while helping protect your business and your customers. Automated updates to libraries and applications also boost security.

These features help make it faster and simpler to meet your security goals. According to the IDC report, the security teams of organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud increased efficiency by 19%. This benefit translates into an average annual business value of $183,016 per organization.

One study participant from the agriculture industry cited the database security standards and policies of SAP HANA Cloud, considering it an extra protective layer to reinforce security. “If we had an on-premises database, we’d lack this added protection,” said the interviewee. “The entire platform has policies that prevent mistakes. For instance, SAP now requires updates to libraries and applications for security reasons. These requirements from SAP keep us updated and secure.”

Another participant from the healthcare industry viewed the advanced protection as a financial advantage. “SAP HANA Cloud is a much more secure system that makes data more accessible and applications perform faster,” he said. “This has helped us meet our customers’ needs much better and has improved our revenue by about five percent.”

A complete application development ecosystem

Time and resources are tight for your development teams. Demand from business users has never been higher, new use cases are emerging, and the need for different developer skill sets seems to continually grow.

SAP HANA Cloud can help address these challenges with an integrated development ecosystem based on SAP Build solutions. SAP Build offers a comprehensive group of tools that support the full spectrum of no-code/low-code, pro-code, and generative AI development approaches. With SAP Build and SAP HANA Cloud, you can support developers at any skill level with the right tools.

Developers can build intelligent applications that use generative AI and harness their expertise and data. Applications built on SAP HANA Cloud can use intelligent algorithms to process large volumes of data and provide actionable recommendations. SAP HANA Cloud also includes machine learning libraries that help developers build sophisticated analytics applications that augment user expertise. By incorporating AI-driven insights, these applications help you anticipate future trends and predict behaviors, make business decisions faster, and improve business performance.

The IDC report found that these application development capabilities deliver quantifiable business value. IDC estimates that development team productivity spiked by 30% in the surveyed organizations, creating staff time savings of $361,519 per organization.  

SAP HANA Cloud features, such as information libraries, combined with faster performance and easier integrations, helped developers build more complex applications such as those using machine learning and AI. Overall, participants developed or deployed 154% more features and applications annually than they could without SAP HANA Cloud.

One study participant explained the impact of this value on the development team. “SAP HANA Cloud provides developers with more seamless integrations, and it is easy to use,” the interviewee explained. “They spend less time writing code because they can reuse code and use the libraries.”

 

Explore additional SAP HANA Cloud resources

As we’ve seen in this , the advanced features of SAP HANA Cloud offer significant value for organizations like yours. To help you make your business case for SAP HANA Cloud, check out the following resources:

  • What’s the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete a short assessment. 
  • Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.
  • Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.
  • Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

[1] “The Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,” IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: Open Source - Apache Superset™ and SAP HANA Comes together to help you
entry.content:
https://superset.apache.org/ 

In today’s data-driven world, organizations need powerful tools to explore, visualize, and act on their data. Apache Superset™, an open-source data visualization platform, combined with SAP HANA, a high-performance in-memory database, offers a robust solution for modern analytics.

Documentation

https://superset.apache.org/docs/6.0.0/intro 

Apache Superset Highlights:

  • Open-source and free to use
  • Rich visualization options (bar charts, pie charts, geospatial maps, etc.)
  • SQL Lab for advanced querying
  • Role-based access control and authentication
  • Cloud-native and scalable architecture

SAP HANA Advantages:

  • In-memory computing for real-time analytics
  • Combines transactional and analytical workloads
  • Advanced analytics (predictive, spatial, text)
  • High performance with large datasets
  • Seamless integration with enterprise systems

Together, they enable real-time, interactive dashboards that empower business users and data analysts alike.

Use Cases

  • Sales Dashboards: Real-time revenue tracking across regions
  • Operations Monitoring: Visualize supply chain metrics
  • Finance Analytics: Profitability and cost breakdowns
  • Customer Insights: Behavioral analysis from SAP CRM data

Final Thoughts

Apache Superset and SAP HANA together form a powerful duo for enterprise-grade analytics. With Superset’s intuitive interface and HANA’s blazing-fast performance, teams can unlock insights faster and make data-driven decisions with confidence.

entry.title: Partners unveil generative AI applications to solve real-time industry challenges with SAP and AWS
entry.content:
AWS SAP AI Co-Innovation Program

At SAP Sapphire 2025, SAP and Amazon Web Services (AWS) unveiled the AI co-innovation program aimed at assisting partners in developing Generative AI applications to address business challenges. This program integrates advanced GenAI technologies from SAP with Generative AI Services from AWS, complemented by SAP Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) Data, to facilitate customer implementation journeys.

As a pivotal advancement in the SAP AI co-innovation program, AWS and SAP have established a new cohort in collaboration with SAP’s well-established Hack2Build initiative. This cohort provides support for the development, testing, and deployment of industry-specific applications. Partners are encouraged to develop industry-focused solutions utilizing AWS generative AI tools and services from Amazon Bedrock, including large language models (LLMs) such as Amazon Nova and Anthropic Claude within AI Foundation on SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). This enables partners to swiftly develop and deploy AI applications tailored to their customers’ SAP workloads.

Hack2Build

Hack2Build Cohort- September 2025 with AWS

 The new cohort of Hack2Build, an initiative of Partner Excellence Center, SAP Partner Ecosystem Success in collaboration with AI Partner Product Management, SAP Business AI and Amazon Web Services, brought together AI expertise from SAP and AWS and architects to expedite the development of partner Generative AI applications within a seven-day timeframe. Ten partners were selected across various regions as part of this initiative. Experts from SAP and AWS provided support and guidance to the selected ten partners on the chosen use cases. The hack phase commenced on September 22nd and concluded with an impressive demo jam on September 30th.

Partners selected for Hack2Build Cohort with AWS and SAP - September 2025

Hack2Build Cohort: 🎉 Winners

 In this blog post, we will delve into the generative AI solutions developed by the winning partners. These solutions leverage the capabilities of Generative AI Hub, a component of SAP AI Core, a service within the SAP Business Technology Platform (SAP BTP). By accessing various Large Language Models (LLMs) on Amazon Web Services (AWS) through the Amazon Bedrock platform, the partners have harnessed the power of generative AI to create innovative solutions.Hack2Build Cohort 2025-Winners' Podium- AWS SAP AI Co-Innovation

🧑‍⚖️🧑🏻‍⚖️ Judges

 On September 30, 2025, a distinguished panel of senior leaders from SAP and AWS convened to select three winners from the demo jam.

  • Kamal Arora, Director of Solutions Architecture and AI Innovation at AWS USA
  • Marc-Oliver Klein, Vice President and Head of Partner Product Management and Strategic AI Development Partnerships at SAP SE
  • Stefan Wellner, Vice President of Technology Alliances, Platform and Incubation Partnerships at SAP Business AI Ecosystem at SAP SE
  • Tom Adams, Director of Global Business Consulting and Advisory Partners at AWS USA 

 🥇 Winner: Atos

Atos presented an AI-Powered Supply Chain Disruption Analysis solution that addresses external vulnerabilities in supply chains, particularly unforeseen disruptions. The solution integrates real-time hazard data with SAP metrics to enhance operational resilience. It also integrates SAP BTP services UI5 and CAP applications with AWS AI services, including the Anthropic Claude 4 Sonnet LLM model on Amazon Bedrock. Key features demonstrated include real-time disruption data collection and automated supplier prioritization integrated with SAP S/4HANA systems.

AI-Powered Supply Chain Disruption Analysis by Atos

🥈1st Runner up - Capgemini

Capgemini demonstrated a GTS smart check solution that seamlessly integrates with SAP GTS and SAP S/4HANA. This solution effectively addresses challenges in import processing, where manual document handling and compliance checks result in delays. The solution significantly reduces import processing time, thereby saving substantial hours annually. This is achieved through the automation of data extraction and comparison from multiple document sources using the Anthropic Claude 4 Sonnet LLM model from Amazon Bedrock.

Capgemini's GTS Smart Check Solution

🥉2nd Runner up - NTT Data

NTT Data unveiled its Voice Control ERP Assistant, a collaborative solution designed to alleviate the challenges associated with accessing ERP systems on the shop floor. This innovative solution addresses the inherent difficulties faced by workers in navigating unfamiliar ERP systems without disrupting their workflow. By seamlessly integrating SAPUI5 and HANA Cloud, SAP HANA Vector Engine, Generative AI Hub within SAP BTP Services, and Anthropic Claude LLM from Amazon Bedrock, including Amazon Polly for voice interaction, the solution enables hands-free access to ERP data and documentation. Specifically targeting the manufacturing industry, the solution demonstrated substantial business value by enhancing task focus and mitigating employee turnover.

Voice Controlled ERP Assistant by NTT Data

👏🏼 Finalists

We thank all the finalist teams who successfully demonstrated the innovations to the panel of judges, as a part of this Hack2Build cohort.

FinalistsMinimal Viable Product demonstrated
AccentureNavi , a smart delivery scheduling solution focusing on the supply chain's inefficiencies in developing countries
CognizantAsset Unitization AI, addresses manual asset unitization challenges in asset-intensive industries
DeloitteRelationship Management Agent, automates the processing of email queries related to supplier and vendor management
IBMSustainable Buddy, addresses sustainability challenges for better operational transparency and efficiency in Oil & Gas
LTIMindtreeFieldSense.ai, enhances SAP Service and Asset Manager to streamline field service operations, improve safety, and ensure compliance in Utilities and Manufacturing
Phoenix ConsultingAutomated Supplier Invoice Processing, addresses high manual effort and error rates in accounts payable ,supporting Arabic characters and Hindu numerals
Tech MahindraImprove PO extraction  and Sales Order creation process, easing the process of extracting data from challenging invoice formats like blurry or multilingual images.

🙏  Special Thanks

We extend our appreciation to the many AWS and SAP experts , who coached the partners to successfully develop their solutions during this Hack2Build initiative.

☞  Next Phase

We anticipate that all participating partners will now proceed to finalize their comprehensive solution within a timeframe of 6 to 8 weeks. SAP and AWS will actively engage with all participating partners to provide support throughout their development process in the upcoming weeks, ensuring that their innovations are prepared for customer deployment.

entry.title: Step-by-Step Guide: Enabling Standard F4 Help for Custom Field created using SAP CFL App
entry.content:
Overview: In SAP, CFL refers to Custom Fields and Logic. It is not a standalone application; rather, it is a Fiori application provided by SAP as a component of S/4HANA Extensibility. The application allows users to incorporate new fields and business logic into standard SAP applications without coding. In this section, we will locate the Custom Fields and Custom Logic tab. Within the Custom Fields tab, we can add our custom fields, while the Custom Logic tab is designated for BAdI implementation, which is currently not in use. For custom logic, we have an additional Fiori application named as Custom Logic.

Introduction: In this blog, we will explore how to add a custom field using the Custom Fields and Logic Fiori application, as well as how to implement standard search help (F4 Help) within that custom field using the SAP Screen Layout of custom created Sub-screen or Main Screen.

Step-by-Step Process:

Step 1 - Open Custom Fields and logic Fiori App.

Step 2 - Press the “+” button located at the top right.

Step 3 - After clicking the “+” button, a pop-up will appear prompting you to enter the appropriate Business Context Id (MM_PURREQN_ITEM) for the corresponding SAP module along with any other necessary fields.

Step 4 - Please choose the correct type from the dropdown menu (such as Text, Code List, etc.). The Text option is solely for input purposes, while the Code List should be used if you wish to assign any fixed values to your field, as other types serve different functions.

Step 5 - Give desired length to the field and click on “Create” Button.

Step 6 - It will appear like this on “Home Page” of the App.

Step 7 - Provide the field label to the field and click on “Save” and “Publish” Button.

Step 8 - In the other tabs, you will find the UI specifications, names of CDS Views, details of the Odata Service, API information, and more.

Step 9 - Once you publish your field, it will be incorporated into the standard table of the relevant business context. In my situation, it will appear in the EBAN table with a name that begins with "ZZ1" under an Append Structure.

Step 10 - Custom sub-screen as a Customer Data tab has been created in the ME51N T-code (Create Purchase Requisition Fiori App) where I have added that custom field.

Step 11 - Open the Screen Layout of the corresponding screen via path System > status > Program Name > Screen > Screen Layout.

Step 12 - Double click on the input field and Properties pop-up will appear.

Step 13 - Enter the standard search help name in the search help field of the property pop-up, and you will notice the F4 help added in the custom field.

Step 14 - Search Help Window.

Conclusion: Using the Custom Fields and Logic app in SAP Fiori, we can easily extend standard applications like ME51N by creating custom fields tailored to business needs. By integrating standard search helps into these fields and placing them on a custom sub screen, we enhance usability while maintaining consistency with SAP’s native behavior. This approach ensures flexibility, upgrade safety, and a smooth user experience—all without needing deep technical development.

This approach will work when you have custom screen, for standard screen we have an alternative option to utilize CDS views F4 help during the creation of fields via Custom fields and logic Fiori App.

entry.title: Step-by-Step: Implementing Generative AI with SAP HANA Cloud
entry.content:
Introduction:

This blog walks through building an AI Sales Assistant on SAP HANA Cloud calculation views. The assistant enables users to ask natural-language questions such as “Which product category had the highest sales in Q2?” and receive contextual answers generated directly from enterprise data.

The solution uses the Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) pattern, where sales transactions stored in HANA are enriched with embeddings and combined with a Large Language Model (LLM) to deliver precise, business-aware responses. This approach extends the analytical power of HANA Cloud with conversational intelligence- effectively bringing AI integration to your calculation views without moving the data out of HANA.

We’ll cover the concepts, high-level architecture, and detailed implementation steps so you can replicate this setup on your own HANA Cloud system and make the most of your existing calculation views.

High Level Architecture:

Key Concepts:

Retrieval-Augmented Generation:

It’s an AI pattern where a language model (like GPT) is not used in isolation, but is “augmented” with external knowledge retrieved from a database or document store.

It has two main steps:

  1. Retrieval – Find the most relevant documents/data from a knowledge source (e.g., database, embeddings index, vector store).

  2. Generation – Pass both the retrieved data + the user’s query into the LLM so the response is grounded in actual facts instead of just relying on the LLM’s training data.

SAP HANA Cloud:
The foundation of this project is SAP HANA Cloud. HANA calculation view serves as the source for the RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) application. With the new HANA Cloud Vector Engine, we can now store and query embeddings directly inside HANA eliminating the need for external vector databases. For this setup, we create a dedicated embeddings table to persist vector representations of the sales data.

Flask API:
For the backend, I used Flask, a lightweight Python web framework.Flask allows Python code to be exposed as REST APIs or lightweight web applications. In this project, the Flask API connects to the HANA calculation view, retrieves data, and interacts with the OpenAI API. OpenAI generates embeddings for the data, which are then stored in the embeddings table in HANA Cloud. The same API also handles user prompts: it takes queries from the frontend, searches the embeddings table, and returns contextual answers. 

Streamlit:
The frontend is built with Streamlit, a Python framework for creating simple yet powerful user interfaces. It provides a chat-like interface where users can enter questions. The prompts are passed to the Flask API, which handles retrieval and reasoning. While Streamlit makes prototyping easy, this frontend could also be replaced with SAP Fiori or any Web frontend.

Implementation steps:

Let’s see step by step on how to develop this framework for existing calculation views.

Prerequisites: Python 3.9+, BAS environment, CF CLI, HANA DB instance, OpenAI API key.

  1. I have two projects in BAS: one containing the HANA calculation views, and the other containing the Flask backend (referred to as the Flask app). Below is the output of the calculation view.

        2.We need to convert the hana data into embeddings and store them in HANA tables. Create embeddings table in HANA cloud. Below is the sql for that. 

CREATE TABLE SALES_EMBEDDINGS (
    TRANSACTION_ID NVARCHAR(50),
    TEXT NVARCHAR(5000),
    EMBEDDING REAL_VECTOR(1536)
);

       3. To generate embeddings using a LLM we need access. In my case i have used LLM from Open AI. Create an account in Open AI and register for Open API key.

       4. Create a python file (eg : generate_embeddings.py) in your flask project to generate embeddings based on your calculation view data and store in HANA cloud table created above. Have your credentials in the env file for testing. Make sure your BAS dev space is in the same region as your HANA cloud instance otherwise connection fails.  This step makes sure we are able to connect to HANA convert calculation view(CV) data into text and generate embeddings for it. Run this file separately and see if data is inserted into HANA cloud table.

import os
from hdbcli import dbapi
from openai import OpenAI
from dotenv import load_dotenv

# Load environment variables
load_dotenv()

# OpenAI client
client = OpenAI(api_key=os.getenv("OPENAI_API_KEY"))

# Connect to SAP HANA Cloud
conn = dbapi.connect(
    address=os.getenv("HANA_HOST"),   # e.g. yourhana.hana.prod-us10.hanacloud.ondemand.com
    port=int(os.getenv("HANA_PORT", "443")),
    user=os.getenv("HANA_USER"),
    password=os.getenv("HANA_PASSWORD")
)

cursor = conn.cursor()

# Fetch sales transactions
cursor.execute("""
    SELECT TRANSACTION_ID, REGION, PRODUCT, SALES_AMOUNT, SALE_DATE 
    FROM schema name."cv_sales_test"
""")
rows = cursor.fetchall()

# 5. Generate embeddings and insert into HANA
for row in rows:
    transaction_id, region, product, sales_amount, sales_date = row
    text = f"Transaction {transaction_id} in {region} sold {product} for {sales_amount} on {sales_date}"
